Friends

class BufferPool

Detailed Description

This class can create, destroy and use memory buffers in a controlled way. Each buffer has a size and a buffer id. A buffer can be larger than the valid bytes it contains: this is expressed by two properties: count and size. The count property is the number of valid bytes (<= size) that the buffer contains.

This class is not thread safe.

Definition at line 47 of file databuf.hpp.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum uStreamLib::DataBuf::AllocStrategy
 

Constants that specify the allocation method. Allocation methods are useful when DataBuf is used with BufferPool class. Memory is allocated on demand or preallocated in the constructor.

Enumeration values:
ALLOC_ONCREATE  Specify this allocation method if you want the DataBuf to allocate memory in the constructor.
ALLOC_ONUSE  Specify this allocation method if you need that the DataBuf allocates memory when copy(), xcopy() and merge() methods are invoked.

void uStreamLib::DataBuf::copy (  char *  data,
uint32  size
) 
 

Copy size bytes in the buffer. The bytes are read from the data array. This method does not stretch the buffer, use xcopy() instead.

Parameters:
data a pointer to a buffer containing the bytes to be copied.
size number of bytes to copy.

void* uStreamLib::DataBuf::getAddr (  void   )  [inline]
 

Get the internal char* pointer. Notice that after a realloc() the returned pointer cannot be used any more and you must recall the getAddr() method.

Returns:
a valid pointer to the data contained in the buffer or NULL if ALLOC_ONUSE is specified and none of copy(), xcopy() and merge() methods have been called.

Definition at line 88 of file databuf.cpp.

int32 uStreamLib::DataBuf::init (  uint32  size,
uint32  bid = 0,
uint32  limit = 65536,
AllocStrategy  strategy = ALLOC_ONCREATE,
BufferPool *  bp = NULL
) 
 

Create a buffer with the specified size, buffer id and limit.

Parameters:
size the initial size of the buffer.
bid the buffer id: this is useful for identifing the buffer during debugging and is heavily used by the BufferPool class to identify a buffer in the pool.
limit a buffer can be limited in size: it cannot grow to more than limit size. Pay attention to this parameter: if you don't know how your buffer is going to grow at runtime, set this to an higher value than default 64k.
Returns:
SUCCESS or FAILURE.

void uStreamLib::DataBuf::move (  int32  to,
int32  from,
uint32  size
) 
 

Move size byte from "from" to "to". This method moves bytes in the buffer. It does not check bounds so it can sigsegv if you pass wrong parameters.

Parameters:
to the destination index in the buffer.
from the source index in the buffer.
size the number of bytes to move.

SUCCESS or FAILURE if no memory is available to stretch the buffer.

)

void uStreamLib::DataBuf::setCount (  uint32  count  )  [inline]
 

Set the number of valid bytes. This method is used when you fill the buffer by other means than those provided by this class. When filling the buffer this way, you must set the right valid bytes count by invoking setCount().

Parameters:
count number of valid bytes.

char* uStreamLib::DataBuf::toString (  void   )  [inline]
 

Utility method to get the string representation of the buffer. Use this method when you know this buffer is a null terminated string.

Returns:
a valid pointer to the data contained in the buffer or NULL if ALLOC_ONUSE is specified and none of copy(), xcopy() and merge() methods have been called.

SUCCESS or FAILURE if no memory is available to stretch the buffer.

SUCCESS or FAILURE if no memory is available to stretch the buffer.
